title-group.article-title: Health Considerations for Children With Congenital Heart Disease in School
title-group.subtitle: Part 2

contrib.aff: Nurse Practitioner, Children’s Hospital Boston, Boston, MA
Nurse Practitioner, Children’s Hospital Boston, Boston, MA
Director of Nursing Research, Arkansas Children’s Hospital, Little Rock, AR
Assistant Director, Michigan Congenital Heart Outcomes Research and Discovery, Michigan Congenital Heart Center, Ann Arbor, MI

abstract.p: School participation for children with congenital heart disease (CHD) can be challenging. Despite advances in treatment that have increased survival to adulthood and decreased morbidity, concerns remain about the health and safety of these students in the school environment. This article, the second in a series, discusses recent research on the increased incidence of neurodevelopmental disabilities that can impact academic performance in children with CHD. Exercise and sports participation is also addressed. School nurses are in a unique position to advocate for the child’s health needs in the school setting and facilitate communication with the health care team and school personnel.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Congenital heart defects (CHD) are the most common birth defect and advances in treatment now allow children with even the most complex defects to survive into adulthood. While many children are fully repaired and have no sequelae of their heart disease, others have health needs that should be addressed to optimize their school experience. In this second article in a series, neurodevelopmental outcomes and exercise and sports issues for students with CHD are discussed.

sec.title: Neurodevelopmental Outcomes
sec.p: Numerous research studies in the past 15 years have elucidated the increased prevalence of neurodevelopmental disabilities in school-age children with CHD even after surgical correction. While intelligence (IQ) is generally in the normal range for the majority of children with CHD, neurodevelopmental disabilities such as learning disabilities, visual motor integration, motor delays, and attention deficit disorders are more common than in the general school age population and can contribute to academic difficulties. As shown in Figure 1, children with milder forms of CHD (e.g., ventricular septal defect) have a low incidence, whereas increasingly complex defects (e.g., transposition of the great arteries) are associated with increasing numbers of children with developmental deficits, and only a minority of children with extremely complex heart defects (e.g., hypoplastic left heart syndrome) are completely normal in all respects (Wernovsky, 2006).

caption.p: Incidence of Developmental Disabilities Related to Severity of Congenital Heart Disease

Note: Schematic representation of developmental abnormalities in children with congenital heart disease. Children with milder forms of congenital heart disease (e.g., ventricular septal defect without an associated genetic syndrome), as a group, have a low incidence of developmental abnormalities, and more than mild abnormalities are rare. Increasingly complex forms of congenital heart disease (e.g., transposition or totally anomalous pulmonary venous connection) are associated with increasing numbers of children with developmental deficits, and only the minority of children with extremely complex heart disease (e.g., functionally univentricular heart, hypoplastic left heart syndrome) are completely normal in all respects. Congenital heart disease associated with chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down’s and DiGeorge Syndromes) or multiple congenital abnormalities are nearly always associated with developmental abnormalities, in many cases, severe.

Source: From “Current Insights Regarding Neurological and Developmental Abnormalities in Children and Young Adults With Complex Congenital Cardiac Disease,” by G. Wernovsky, 2006, Cardiology in the Young, 16(Suppl. 1), 92-104. Copyright 2006 by Cambridge University Press. Adapted with permission.

sec.p: Multiple factors in the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative period may be responsible for the prevalence of neurodevelopmental disabilities in these children. There is an increased incidence of structural abnormalities of the brain in children with CHD (Wernovsky, 2006). Preoperative and postoperative conditions such as severe acidosis and hypoxia, hemodynamic instability and low cardiac output, or altered cerebral blood flow can contribute to neurodevelopmental disabilities (Hovels-Gurich et al., 2002, 2008; Mahle & Wernovsky, 2001). Cardiopulmonary bypass, used with most cardiac surgeries, involves a potential risk of embolic complications and some bypass techniques are associated with negative neurodevelopmental outcomes (Bellinger et al., 1999; Forbess et al., 2002; Limperopoulos et al., 2002; Wernovsky et al., 2000).

Some school-age children with CHD require additional academic supports with special education services. An individualized education plan (IEP) may be needed to address learning disabilities, problems with visual motor integration, gross and fine motor delays, speech impairments, inattention, hyperactivity, or other behavioral problems (Hovels-Gurich et al., 2002; Miatton, De Wolf, Francois, Thiery, & Vingerhoets, 2007; Wernovsky, 2006). It is important to note that these problems are identified even in children with normal intelligence scores on routine screening. Multiple studies have identified deficits in visual-motor or visual-spatial skills, especially in children with hypoplastic left heart syndrome or other forms of complex single ventricle (Forbess et al., 2002; Karsdorp, Everaerd, Kindt & Mulder, 2007; Mahle et al., 2006). Holm, Fredriksen, Fosdahl, Olstad, and Vollestad (2007) reported that children with CHD have a risk of impaired motor competence or severe motor problems that is almost 6 and 11 times, respectively, that of healthy age- and sex-matched children.

Attention deficit disorders, such as ADHD, are also more prevalent in children with CHD, especially those with current cyanosis or previous cyanotic lesions, than in the general population (Hovels-Gurich et al., 2007; Kirshbom et al., 2004, McCrindle et al., 2006; Shillingford et al., 2008; Shillingford & Wernovsky, 2004). In one study of children with complex CHD, the number of children receiving clinically significant scores for inattention and hyperactivity was 3 to 4 times higher than observed in the general population (Shillingford et al., 2008).

Students with CHD can be safely treated with stimulant drugs for ADHD following assessment by a comprehensive cardiac health history and physical examination. Previous reports of adverse cardiovascular events with stimulant medications, including sudden death, have been refuted by recent large cohort studies showing no increased risk with these drugs (Cooper et al., 2011; Schelleman et al., 2011). Minor alterations in heart rate and blood pressure may occur.

As these children progress through school, learning disabilities, behavior problems, and attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, if not addressed, may result in academic failure, poor classroom and social skills, low self-esteem, behavioral disinhibition, and ultimate delinquency (Wernovsky, 2006). Wernovsky (2006) further notes that the combined outcomes of developmental delay, academic difficulties, and behavioral abnormalities represent the single most common morbidity affecting the quality of life in school-aged children with CHD.

Identification of neurodevelopmental disabilities is key to effective intervention strategies. Many children will have significant problems at school that were not predicted in infancy (McGrath, Wypij, Rappaport, Newburger & Bellinger, 2004). A higher index of suspicion for the presence of cognitive and behavioral problems in children with CHD may lead to earlier recognition and diagnosis. When there is a need for special education services for these students, interventions must be tailored to the child’s specific needs (Bellinger et al., 2003; Dunbar-Masterson et al., 2001; Mahle et al., 2006). Recommendations from the American Heart Association for the evaluation and management of neurodevelopmental issues in children with CHD were recently published (Marino et al., 2012).

sec.title: Exercise and Sports
sec.p: Developmentally, children have a fundamental need to move and play. Regular sports and exercise promote normal development and encourages self-esteem and acceptance into peer groups. Sports teach children teamwork, perseverance, and respect for teammates and opponents. Weight control is another important benefit of regular exercise. Pinto and colleagues (2007) found that more than 25% of children with heart disease were obese or overweight, a finding that parallels the national average in healthy children.

The hemodynamic demands of exercise produce a more than five-fold increase in cardiac output, which is accompanied by an increase in pulmonary and systemic blood pressures. CHD associated with ventricular dysfunction, residual shunts (abnormal connections allowing excessive blood flow into a chamber or allowing oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix), valvular disorders, and sinus node disease may impede the normal cardiopulmonary response to exercise (Rhodes et al., 2006). Despite these physiological deficits, nearly all children with heart disease can participate in some sort of exercise program or sport.

There are two types of exercise, dynamic and static. Dynamic exercise is exercise performed with large muscle mass, which results in marked increase in oxygen consumption, cardiac output, heart rate, stroke volume, and systolic blood pressure (e.g., cycling, jogging) (Maron, Isner, & McKenna, 1994). Dynamic exercise primarily causes a volume load on the left ventricle. Static exercise involves development of a relatively large intramuscular force with little or no change in muscle length or joint movement (e.g., body building, football). Static exercise causes a marked increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure placing a pressure load on the cardiovascular system. Both dynamic and static exercises can be performed at low, moderate, or high levels of intensity (see Table 1). The hemodynamic consequences of exercise are considered in the cardiologists recommendations for physical activities.

caption.p: Levels of Static and Dynamic Exercise

fn.p: Source: From “36th Bethesda Conference: Eligibility Recommendations for Competitive Athletes With Cardiovascular Abnormalities. Task Force 8: Classification of Sports,” by J. H. Mitchell, W. Haskell, P. Snell, and S. P. Van Camp, 2005, Journal of the American College of Cardiology, 45, 1364-1367. Copyright 2005 by American College of Cardiology Foundation. Adapted with permission.

sec.p: The 36th Bethesda Conference drafted the most recent guidelines on exercise and sports participation for children with CHD (Graham et al., 2005). With rare exceptions, students with hemodynamically insignificant CHD may participate competitively in all sports. Although children with more serious congenital or residual heart anomalies are advised to avoid high-intensity competitive sports, these recommendations do not necessarily preclude participation in these activities in a less competitive, recreational environment. Thus, they may be restricted from playing competitive basketball on a team but be allowed to shoot baskets at their own pace on the playground.

Recommendations concerning sports participation can change over time and are based on the child’s diagnosis, current treatment status (e.g., postprocedure), disease severity, residual cardiac disease if any, and potential risks for injury. If in doubt about specific sports or exercise activities, further discussion with the cardiology team is recommended. See Table 2 for a list of heart defects most likely to have exercise restrictions.

caption.p: Congenital Heart Diseases That Generally Require Exercise Restrictions

tr.td: Aortic coarctation with a residual blood pressure gradient
Moderate pulmonary stenosis with > 50 mm Hg gradient across the pulmonary valve
Moderate Ebsteins anomaly of the tricuspid valve associated with significant tricuspid regurgitation
Kawasaki disease with subsequent coronary artery anomalies
Children with pacemakers or those on anticoagulation

fn.p: Source: Adapted from “36th Bethesda Conference: Eligibility Recommendations for Competitive Athletes With Cardiovascular Abnormalities. Task Force 2: Congenital Heart Disease,” by T. P. Graham, Jr., D. J. Driscoll, W. M. Gersony, J. W. Newburger, A. Rocchini, and J. A. Tobin, 2005, Journal of the American College of Cardiology, 45, 735-1097. Copyright 2005 by American College of Cardiology Foundation. Adapted with permission.

sec.p: Contact sports can pose significant danger due to bodily collision with a competitor or an object (e.g., soccer ball, hockey puck, punches). These injuries pose real concerns for children with connective tissue abnormalities or arrhythmias, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with indwelling pacemakers or implantable cardiac defibrillators. Use of protective devices while playing sports, including chest protectors, padded pacemaker pockets, and the use of helmets for children on anticoagulation medications, should be considered. Participation in organized contact sports should be discussed with the child’s cardiologist so clear guidelines can be established; appropriate safety precautions taken; and this information communicated to teachers, coaches, and trainers.

sec.title: Sudden Cardiac Death in Athletes
sec.p: Although there are many concerns that children with CHD are at greater risk of sudden death while exercising, this is not the case. Congenital heart defects account for only 2% of sudden cardiac deaths in children (Graham et al., 2005). Children and adolescents with genetic cardiovascular diseases such as Marfan Syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, Long QT syndrome, Brugada syndrome, arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD), and catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT) account for 40% of sudden cardiac deaths in athletes (Maron et al., 2004).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Individualized health and educational plans may be needed for some students with CHD to allow them to participate as fully as possible in school and athletic activities. The increased incidence of learning disabilities, attention deficit disorder and other developmental delays, and behavioral issues is well recognized in this population and can have a significant effect on academic performance. Early recognition of learning and behavior problems allows for educational interventions and special education services geared to a child’s individual needs. The safety of various exercise and sports activities for children with CHD should be discussed with the student, family, cardiologist, and school personnel. Communication with the cardiology team about individual children can often be facilitated by the advanced practice nurse in the cardiac referral center, encouraging joint problem solving. School nurses are in a unique position to advocate for the child’s health needs in the school setting, educate school personnel, participate in the IEP process, and prepare emergency plans. All caregivers share the same goal of a healthy school environment for every child, which allows them to reach their full potential.■

ack.p: The authors are members of the Pediatric Cardiovascular Nursing Committee of the Council on Cardiovascular Nursing, American Heart Association.

bio.p: Patricia O’Brien has practiced in pediatric cardiology, cardiac surgery, and heart transplantation at Children’s Hospital, Boston, for more than 25 years and currently coordinates regional referrals and practices in outpatient cardiology.

Juli-anne Evangelista has more than 22 years’ experience in ambulatory pediatric cardiology at Children’s Hospital, Boston, and currently staffs the satellite cardiology clinics providing assessment, diagnosis, management, and treatment of children with congenital and acquired heart disease.

Angela Green is the Director of Nursing Research at Arkansas Children’s Hospital and is a clinical associate professor at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences College of Nursing. Her areas of research are psychosocial outcomes after pediatric heart transplantation and evidence-based practice implementation.

Karen Uzark has more than 30 years’ clinical experience in pediatric cardiology, including management of pediatric heart transplant recipients. Her research focuses on quality of life and other outcomes in this patient population.
